themes.title: Nature-Inspired Aesthetics in Literati Culture
points: Discuss how the literati valued beauty inspired by nature, as seen in the decorative themes of their studio objects (Chunk 1, Chunk 4).
Highlight the connection between art and philosophy, emphasizing how natural motifs symbolized harmony and balance in Chinese culture.
Engage students by asking them to identify nature-inspired designs in the exhibit and speculate on their symbolic meanings.

themes.title: Export Wares and Global Trade
points: Explain how blue-and-white wares from southern Chinese kilns were created for export, showcasing China's role in global trade (Chunk 2).
Relate this to the class interest in import/export by discussing how these wares influenced European ceramics and art styles.
Ask students to consider what modern objects are exported globally and how cultural exchange shapes design trends.

themes.title: Chemistry of Porcelain and Glazing
points: Introduce the porcelain item with celadon glaze and explain the chemical processes involved in creating the glaze (Chunk 3).
Describe the firing process, including the three-stage decoration and firing that made these objects luxurious (Chunk 5).
Connect this to the tour guide's chemistry background by discussing the role of temperature and chemical reactions in achieving specific colors and finishes.

themes.title: Luxury and Craftsmanship
points: Discuss how the complex firing and decoration techniques elevated these objects to luxury status (Chunk 5).
Explore the cultural significance of owning such items in literati society and how they reflected wealth and intellectual refinement.
Encourage students to think about how craftsmanship and luxury are valued in their own culture today.
